title: I gave the police access to my DNA—and maybe some of yours

speedrun: The article discusses the author's decision to share their DNA profile with law enforcement through FamilyTreeDNA, highlighting the implications of using genealogical databases in criminal investigations. This practice, which helped solve the Golden State Killer case, raises significant ethical questions about privacy and consent in the age of genetic data sharing.
why_it_matters: This trend could lead to more cold cases being solved, but it also poses risks to individual privacy and the potential misuse of genetic information.
As law enforcement increasingly relies on genealogical databases, it may create a chilling effect on public participation in genetic testing and family history research.

lenses.eli12: The author shared their DNA with police to help solve crimes. This is cool because it can catch bad guys, but it also means your DNA could be used without your full understanding. It raises questions about privacy.
lenses.pm: Law enforcement agencies will use this approach to solve cold cases and identify suspects more efficiently. It addresses the challenge of limited leads in investigations, but also poses risks of public backlash against privacy violations.
lenses.engineer: The technical approach involves uploading crime-scene DNA to genealogical databases, leveraging algorithms to match profiles. While this method can yield quick results, it faces limitations in accuracy and potential ethical concerns regarding consent and data security.
